issue.title: Feature Request: Expose Password Hash Obscure Function

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
Related to #1010 

I'm hoping to have the Obscuring function from the Config command exposed in a way that allows me to run a password against it and get the output that would go in the "password = xxxx" and "password2 = xxxxx" fields of the .rclone.conf.

This seems to be an absolute blocker for any type of scripted config / install where CLI input isn't available. Am I missing something? thanks!

Btw, side note: Been using rclone mount with crypt for a couple of days and it has worked amazingly...way better than some of the other solutions out there. Very glad to have the project available. Thanks so much!!!

body:
I recently merged something which will allow you to configure rclone through environment variables - see #616 - does that help?

I'm not sure how you would script the oauth login - how do you see that working?

It's definitely a step in the right direction.

The biggest hurdle I ran in to last night (high level) was generating the .rclone.conf. Breaking down the detail of the hurdle, the two primary issues are: 1) Inputing the obscured password and 2) generating the oauth token.

In general, if we want to consider rclone (binary) to be usable in a hands off way, it needs to require a no input workflow. I saw that there are auto_config options in the internal functions, but the primary workflow (rclone config) definitely requires input (even to use the environmental variables) from what I understand.

For the Oauth portion: I think the path of least resistance would be to have a flag that would trigger the http server with the right id and name and await web input).

Something like:

rclone writeconfig --name NAME --TYPE ACD --OTHEROPT OTHERVALUE --auth http --httpPort 12345 --httpRedirect http://www.whatever.com --httpBind 0.0.0.0

This could write the initial config and then launch the http server that is there with the right variables (and maybe a timeout by default).

I think all the parts are there, just needs a new workflow path.

As it is 2019 today, may I ask if there are any best practice for non-interactive config (or at least semi-interactive - only the oauth part) regarding rclone config?

Example:
rclone config --name=googledrive --type=drive --scope=rw --headless

which should only prompt me for the Authorization code from Google OAuth2 ...

@tamama 

check out the `rclone config` sub commands - you can use these to create config values.

```
$ rclone config -h
Enter an interactive configuration session where you can setup new
remotes and manage existing ones. You may also set or remove a
password to protect your configuration.

Usage:
  rclone config [flags]
  rclone config [command]

Available Commands:
  create      Create a new remote with name, type and options.
  delete      Delete an existing remote <name>.
  dump        Dump the config file as JSON.
  edit        Enter an interactive configuration session.
  file        Show path of configuration file in use.
  password    Update password in an existing remote.
  providers   List in JSON format all the providers and options.
  show        Print (decrypted) config file, or the config for a single remote.
  update      Update options in an existing remote.

Flags:
  -h, --help   help for config

Use "rclone [command] --help" for more information about a command.
Use "rclone help flags" for to see the global flags.
Use "rclone help backends" for a list of supported services.
```

Note that you can use rclone without a config file - every config file value can be passed in as a flag or as an environment variable.

@ncw May I know the flag to disable auto-config? (My server is a headless one...)

Here is a simple log:
--------------------
[root@london-node-230 ~]# rclone config create gdrive drive --drive-scope="drive" --auto-confirm=false
Remote config
If your browser doesn't open automatically go to the following link: http://127.0.0.1:53682/auth
Log in and authorize rclone for access
Waiting for code...

(cont'd) What I really want is:

Remote config
Use auto config?
 * Say Y if not sure
 * Say N if you are working on a remote or headless machine or Y didn't work
y) Yes
n) No
y/n> n
If your browser doesn't open automatically go to the following link: https://accounts.google.com/o/oauth2/auth?access_type=offline&client_id=202264815644.apps.googleusercontent.com&redirect_uri=urn%3Aietf%3Awg%3Aoauth%3A2.0%3Aoob&response_type=code&scope=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.googleapis.com%2Fauth%2Fdrive&state=301258b83e6f52f5ab58dc9043719b00
Log in and authorize rclone for access

@tamama I've had a go at fixing this.

Please try

https://beta.rclone.org/branch/v1.45-095-g40179518-fix-1010-script-config-beta/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

You'll need to use this (note the parameters are `key` `value` pairs from the config file).

    rclone config create gdrive drive scope drive config_is_local false

@ncw This works perfectly! (The rclone binary that I used is from rclone-v1.45-095-g40179518-fix-1010-script-config-beta-linux-amd64.zip)

Please kindly tell me when this patch will be available in the official beta branch, so that 
curl https://rclone.org/install.sh | bash -s beta 

would work.

Thanks!
@ncw I think that your rclone project would be a killer when integrated with configuration management tools, such as Puppet or Ansible. Truly unbeatable. Awesomely done!
